[[Yemen]] |- | {{mono|894}} || [[Zambia]] |}
===User-assigned code elements===<!--This section is linked from [[ISO 3166-1]]--> User-assigned code elements are codes at the disposal of users who need to add further names of countries, territories, or other geographical entities to their in-house application of ISO 3166-1, and the ISO 3166/MA will never use these codes in the updating process of the standard. The numeric codes {{mono|900}} to {{mono|999}} can be user-assigned.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.iso.org/glossary-for-iso-3166.html| title=Glossary for ISO 3166 - Codes for countries and their subdivisions| publisher=ISO}}</ref>
==Withdrawn codes== When countries merge, split, or undergo territorial change, their numeric codes are withdrawn and new numeric codes are assigned. For example: * [[East Germany]] and [[West Germany]] used numeric codes {{mono|278}} and {{mono|280}} respectively before their unification in 1990. Since then, the unified [[Germany]] has used numeric code {{mono|276}}, while keeping the alphabetic codes for West Germany. * [[Ethiopia]] used numeric code {{mono|230}} before [[Eritrea]] split away in 1993. Since then, Ethiopia has used numeric code {{mono|231}}, while keeping the same alphabetic codes. * [[Sudan]] used numeric code {{mono|736}} before [[South Sudan]] split away in 2011. Since then, Sudan has used numeric code {{mono|729}}, while keeping the same alphabetic codes.
If a country changes its name without any territorial change, its numeric code remains the same. For example, when [[Burma]] was renamed Myanmar without territorial change in 1989, its alphabetic codes were changed, but its numeric code {{mono|104}} has remained the same.
The following numeric codes have been withdrawn from ISO 3166-1:<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.davros.org/misc/iso3166.html#disused| title=Country codes in ISO 3166 (Table 2: codes withdrawn from use)| author=Clive Feather| date=2003-07-25}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Code ! Country name ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | {{mono|128}} || [[Canton and Enderbury Islands]] |- | {{mono|200}} || [[Czechoslovakia]] |- | {{mono|216}} || [[Queen Maud Land|Dronning Maud Land]] |- | {{mono|230}} || [[Ethiopia]] || before [[Eritrea]] split away in 1993 |- | {{mono|249}} || [[Metropolitan France|France, Metropolitan]] |- | {{mono|278}} || [[East Germany|German Democratic Republic]] || i.e., East Germany |- | {{mono|280}} || [[West Germany|Germany, Federal Republic of]] || i.e., West Germany |- | {{mono|396}} || [[Johnston Atoll|Johnston Island]] |- | {{mono|488}} || [[Midway Atoll|Midway Islands]] |- | {{mono|530}} || [[Netherlands Antilles]] || after [[Aruba]] split away in 1986 |- | {{mono|532}} || Netherlands Antilles || before Aruba split away in 1986 |- | {{mono|536}} || [[Saudi–Iraqi neutral zone|Neutral Zone]] |- | {{mono|582}} || [[Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands|Pacific Islands (Trust Territory)]] |- | {{mono|590}} || [[Panama]] || before adding [[Panama Canal Zone]] in 1979 |- | {{mono|658}} || [[Saint Christopher-Nevis-Anguilla|Saint Kitts-Nevis-Anguilla]] |- | {{mono|720}} || [[South Yemen|Yemen, Democratic]] || i.e., South Yemen |- | {{mono|736}} || [[Sudan]] || before [[South Sudan]] split away in 2011 |- | {{mono|810}} || [[Soviet Union|USSR]] |- | {{mono|849}} || [[United States Miscellaneous Pacific Islands|United States Miscellaneous Pacific Islands]] |- | {{mono|872}} || [[Wake Island]] |- | {{mono|886}} || [[North Yemen|Yemen Arab Republic]] || i.e., North Yemen |- | {{mono|890}} || [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia, Socialist Federal Republic of]] |- | {{mono|891}} || [[Serbia and Montenegro]] || original name: [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia, Federal Republic of]] |}
The following numeric codes were also assigned by the United Nations Statistics Division, but these territories were never officially included in ISO 3166-1:<ref name="iarc" />
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Code ! Territory name |- | {{mono|274}} || [[Gaza Strip|Gaza Strip (Palestine)]] |- | {{mono|282}} || [[East Berlin|German Democratic Republic, Berlin]] |- | {{mono|284}} || [[West Berlin|Germany, West Berlin]] |- | {{mono|650}} || [[Ryukyu Islands]] |- | {{mono|728}} || [[Plazas de soberanía|Spanish North Africa]] (note: this code is now used by [[South Sudan]]) |- | {{mono|830}} || [[Channel Islands]] |}
In the [[UN M.49]] standard developed by the United Nations Statistics Division, additional numeric codes are used to represent geographical regions and groupings of countries and areas for statistical processing purposes, but these codes are not included in ISO 3166-1. Unlike alphabetic codes, there are no reserved numeric codes in ISO 3166-1.
==References== <references />
==Sources and external links== * [https://www.iso.org/iso-3166-country-codes.html ISO 3166 Maintenance Agency], International Organization for Standardization (ISO) * [http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49.htm ''Standard Country or Area Codes for Statistical Use''], United Nations Statistics Division ** [http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49alpha.htm Countries or areas, codes and abbreviations] — list of alpha-3 and numeric codes (a few territories officially assigned codes in ISO 3166-1 are not included in this list) ** [http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49regin.htm Composition of macro geographical (continental) regions, geographical sub-regions, and selected economic and other groupings] ** [http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49chang.htm Country or area numerical codes added or changed since 1982] * ''[[The World Factbook]]'' (public domain), Central Intelligence Agency ** [https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/appendix/appendix-d.html Appendix D – Cross-Reference List of Country Data Codes] — comparison of FIPS 10, ISO 3166, and STANAG 1059 country codes * [http://www.statoids.com/ Administrative Divisions of Countries ("Statoids")], Statoids.com ** [http://www.statoids.com/wab.html Country codes] — comparison of ISO 3166-1 country codes with other country codes ** [http://www.statoids.com/w3166his.html ISO 3166-1 Change History]
{{-}} {{ISO 3166}} {{Geocoding-systems}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox software | name = JOSM | logo = JOSM Logo 2014.svg | logo size = 100px | screenshot = JOSM_screenshot_hoofdscherm.png | screenshot size = 240px | caption = JOSM with single OpenStreetMap data layer (standard rendering style) | author = Immanuel Scholz | developer = Dirk Stöcker and other contributors | released = {{Start date and age|2006|01|22}}<ref name="josm-1.0">{{Cite web |url=https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk/2006-January/002163.html# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-05-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160918033147/https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk/2006-January/002163.html# |archive-date=2016-09-18 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> | latest release version = {{#invoke:Wikidata|claim|P348}} | latest release date = {{#invoke:Wikidata|claim|P348|qualifier=P577}}<ref name=changelog>{{cite web|url=https://josm.openstreetmap.de/wiki/Changelog|title=Changelog – JOSM|website=Josm.openstreetmap.de}}</ref> | programming language = [[Java (programming language)|Java]] (version 8 or later<ref name=changelog/>) | platform = [[Cross-platform]] ([[Windows]], [[macOS]], [[Linux]]) | genre = [[GIS software]] | language count = 34<ref>{{cite web|url=https://josm.openstreetmap.de/svn/trunk/data/|title=svn - Revision 10787: /trunk/data|website=Josm.openstreetmap.org}}</ref> | license = [[GNU General Public License|GNU GPL v2]] }} '''JOSM''' ({{Audio|GT JOSM.ogg|listen}}) ''(Java OpenStreetMap Editor)'' is a [[free software]] desktop editing tool for [[OpenStreetMap]] [[geodata]] created in [[Java (programming language)|Java]], originally developed by Immanuel Scholz and currently maintained by Dirk Stöcker.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/JOSM|title=JOSM|website=Wiki.openstreetmap.org}}</ref> It has a lot of advanced features,<ref>{{cite book |editors=Jokar Arsanjani, J., Zipf, A., Mooney, P., Helbich, M. |date=2015 |title=OpenStreetMap in GIScience: Experiences, Research, and Applications|url=https://www.springer.com/us/book/9783319142791 |location= |publisher=Springer |page=71 |isbn=978-3-319-14280-7}}</ref> but also more complicated [[user interface]] than default online editor [[iD (software)|iD]].
== Features == [[File:Josm presets de.png|thumb|JOSM road presets menu in German]] Some notable features of JOSM are importing [[GPS Exchange Format|GPX]] files (GPS tracks),<ref>{{cite book |date=2013 |title=Geographic Information Systems: Concepts, Methodologies, Tools, and Applications |url=http://www.igi-global.com/book/geographic-information-systems/66203 |location=USA |publisher=Information Resources Management Association |page=546 |isbn=1466620382}}</ref> working with [[aerial imagery]] (including [[Web Map Service|WMS]], [[Tile Map Service|TMS]] and [[Web Map Tile Service|WMTS]] protocols), support for multiple [[cartographic projection]]s, layers, relations editing,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mapbox.com/blog/josm-relations/|title=Mapping complex features in JOSM using relations|first=Ruth|last=Maben|website=Mapbox.ocm}}</ref> data validation tools, data filtering, offline work,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Comparison_of_editors#JOSM|title=Comparison of editors - OpenStreetMap Wiki|website=Wiki.openstreetmap.org}}</ref> presets and rendering styles.<ref name="PacktPub">{{cite book | url=https://www.packtpub.com/books/content/checking-openstreetmap-data-problems | title=OpenStreetMap | publisher=PacktPub | date=September 2010 | accessdate=22 May 2016 | author=Bennett Jonathan | ISBN=9781847197504}}</ref> JOSM provides more than 200 [[keyboard shortcut]]s for the core functions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://josm.openstreetmap.de/wiki/DevelopersGuide/ShortcutsList|title=DevelopersGuide/ShortcutsList – JOSM|website=Josm.openstreetmap.org}}</ref>
Many additional features (like tools for drawing buildings, adding Wikipedia links or viewing data in 3D) are available through the [[plug-in (computing)|plugins]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://learnosm.org/en/josm/josm-plugins/|title=LearnOSM|website=Learnosm.org}}</ref><ref name="Linux Weekly News">{{cite web | url=https://lwn.net/Articles/322163/ | title=OpenStreetMap: the data behind the maps | publisher=Linux Weekly News | date=March 6, 2009 | accessdate=22 May 2016 | author=Chance Tom}}</ref><ref name="osm-traffic-simulation">{{cite web | url=https://depositonce.tu-berlin.de/handle/11303/4976 | title=OpenStreetMap for traffic simulation | publisher=Technische Universitat Berlin Collection | date=2 September 2015 | accessdate=22 May 2016 |author1=Michael Zilske |author2=Andreas Neumann |author3=Kai Nagel }}</ref><ref name="annotation-edition-josm-plugin">{{cite web | url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1877042814001451 | title=Annotation edition JOSM Plugin, in A framework and a tool for semantic annotation of POIs in OpenStreetMap | publisher=Procedia - Social and Behavioral Sciences, Volume 111, Pages 1092–1101 | date=5 February 2014 | accessdate=22 May 2016 |author1=F Scioscia |author2=M Binetti |author3=M Ruta |author4=S Ieva |author5=Eugenio Di Sciascio }}</ref> There are more than 100 of them in the repository.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://svn.openstreetmap.org/applications/editors/josm/plugins/|title=- Revision 32802|website=Svn.openstreetmap.org}}</ref>
== History == First changeset was created on 27 September 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://josm.openstreetmap.de/changeset/1/josm|title=Changeset 1 – JOSM|website=Josm.openstreetmap.de}}</ref> First beta version (which required Java 5)<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk/2005-October/001181.html# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-05-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161211011011/https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk/2005-October/001181.html# |archive-date=2016-12-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> was made available on 4 October 2005 and JOSM 1.0 has been released on 22 January 2006.<ref name="josm-1.0"/> Current versioning scheme, using code [[changeset]] number, was introduced in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/josmeditor/diary/38165|title=OpenStreetMap - josmeditor's diary - JOSM reaches version 10000 in its 10th year|website=Openstreetmap.org}}</ref>
In 2014 project logo has been replaced with the new artwork, which won a design contest.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.openstreetmap.org/2014/12/12/josm-new-logo/|title=A new logo for JOSM, the Java OpenStreetMap Editor - OpenStreetMap Blog|website=Blog.openstrretmap.org}}</ref> From this year stable releases are identified with additional YY.MM internal version number (following r6763 - 14.01<ref>{{cite web | url=https://josm.openstreetmap.de/wiki/Changelog/2014#a2014-01-27:Stablereleaser676314.01 | title=2014 Changelog | accessdate=7 November 2016}}</ref>), however they may not exactly reflect the release date.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/josm-dev/2016-November/007774.html | title=16.10 release | publisher=The josm-dev Archives | date=6 November 2016 | accessdate=7 November 2016 | author=Legner, Simon}}</ref>
Since revision 10786 (16.07) released on 12 August 2016 support for Java versions earlier than 8 has been dropped.<ref name=changelog/>
== Usage == The highest number of edits in OSM is done using JOSM.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Editor_usage_stats#by_number_of_edits|title=Editor usage stats - OpenStreetMap Wiki|website=Wiki.openstreetmap.org}}</ref> The software was used to perform several large scale OSM imports, including [[Topologically Integrated Geographic Encoding and Referencing|TIGER]] data in the United States.<ref name="Tiger">{{cite web | url=https://www.linux.com/news/openstreetmap-project-completes-import-united-states-tiger-data | title=OpenStreetMap project completes import of United States TIGER data | website=Linux.com | date=23 January 2008 | accessdate=22 May 2016 | author=Nathan Willis}}</ref>
JOSM can also be used for editing an OSM sister project [[OpenHistoricalMap]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Open_Historical_Map#Editing_OHM|title=Open Historical Map - OpenStreetMap Wiki|website=Wiki.openstreetmap.org}}</ref> It's included as a [[Package manager|package]] in many Linux distributions like [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]],<ref name="ubuntu">{{cite web | url=https://help.ubuntu.com/community/JOSM | title=JOSM | website=Help.ubuntu.com | date=10 December 2009 | accessdate=22 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://wiki.ubuntuusers.de/JOSM/ | title=JOSM | website=Ubuntuusers.de | date=22 April 2016 | accessdate=22 May 2016}}</ref> [[Debian]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://packages.debian.org/jessie/josm|title=Debian -- Details of package josm in jessie|website=Packages.debian.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-06}}</ref> [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://admin.fedoraproject.org/pkgdb/package/rpms/josm/|title=rpms/josm {{!}} PkgDB|website=Admin.fedoraproject.org|access-date=2017-04-06}}</ref> [[Arch Linux]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.archlinux.org/packages/community/any/josm/|title=Arch Linux - josm 11826-1 (any)|website=Archlinux.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-06}}</ref> and the [[Open Source Geospatial Foundation|OSGEO]] [[Live DVD]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://live.osgeo.org/en/overview/osm_overview.html | title=OSGEO-DVD | publisher=OSGEO | accessdate=22 May 2016}}</ref>
Various tutorials are available. The LearnOSM Tutorial, translated in 16 languages, has a section on JOSM.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://learnosm.org/en/josm/|title=LearnOSM|website=Learnosm.org}}</ref> It covers the editing process, the tools, the plugins, the presets, the imagery functionalities, conflict resolution and other features. {{-}} == References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == {{commons category|JOSM}} * {{official website}} * [https://josm.openstreetmap.de/wiki/Help JOSM help system] * [https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/JOSM JOSM page on OSM Wiki]
{{OpenStreetMap}}
[[Category:Free GIS software]] [[Category:OpenStreetMap]]

[[File:Kambojika Putta Khemara Tarei (front).jpg|thumb|right|300px|On display next to [[Royal Palace, Phnom Penh|Royal Palace]] in [[Phnom Penh]].]] '''Kambojika Putta Khemara Tarei''' ([[Khmer language|Khmer]]: កម្ពោជិកបុត្តាខេមរាតរី) is a [[dragon boat]] from [[Cambodia]]. The boat holds the [[Guinness World Records|Guinness record]] of being the longest dragon boat in the world. With an overall length of {{convert|87.3|m|ft}}, in November 2018, the boat beat the previous record of {{convert|77.8|m|ft}} set by a Chinese dragon boat in May 2016.<ref name="Record set for world’s longest dragon boat">{{cite news|title=Record set for world’s longest dragon boat|publisher=[[The Phnom Penh Post]]|accessdate=28 November 2018|url=https://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/record-set-worlds-longest-dragon-boat}}</ref> The boat was showcased during the 2018 [[Water Festival]] in [[Phnom Penh]].
==History== The boat was built to remember the history of production and use of dragon boats by the [[Khmer people]] and [[Monarchy of Cambodia|Khmer kings]] in older times, who used dragon boats as means of transport to defend the territory.<ref name="Recording longest dragon boat">{{cite news|title=Recording longest dragon boat|publisher=xinhuanet.com|accessdate=28 November 2018|url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-11/12/c_137600775.htm}}</ref> The boat was built by ''Union of Youth Federations of Cambodia'' at an overall cost of {{US$|60000|2018}}. Construction of the boat began in April 2018 and it took nearly seven months to finish the construction. The boat measures {{convert|87.3|m|ft}} in overall length, {{convert|1.99|m|ft}} in width and it can accommodate 179 [[oarsman]].<ref name="Cambodia sets world record for longest boat">{{cite news|title=Cambodia sets world record for longest boat|publisher=[[The Manila Times]]|accessdate=28 November 2018|url=https://www.manilatimes.net/cambodia-sets-world-record-for-longest-boat/467195/}}</ref><ref name="Cambodia breaks Guinness World Records">{{cite news|title=Cambodia breaks Guinness World Records|publisher=China daily|accessdate=28 November 2018|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/a/201811/12/WS5be91b36a310eff303288192.html}}</ref><ref name="Cambodia sets new record">{{cite news|title=Cambodia sets new record|publisher=Cambodia daily|accessdate=28 November 2018|url=https://www.cambodiadaily.com/news/cambodia-sets-new-record-for-worlds-longest-dragon-boat-142296/}}</ref> More than 13,000 people participated in the construction of the boat and it was completely [[Handicraft|hand-made]].<ref name="Longest boat on display in capital">{{cite news|title=Longest boat on display in capital|publisher=[[Khmer Times]]|accessdate=28 November 2018|url=https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50552836/longest-boat-on-display-in-capital/}}</ref>
The name ''Kambojika Putta Khemara Tarei'' translates to “Dragon Boat of Khmer Youth in Cambodian Territory".<ref name="Record set for world’s longest dragon boat"/>
The 179 oarsman in the boat symbolizes the day Cambodia was liberated from [[Khmer Rouge]] (7 January 1979); 1 being the month and 79 the year.<ref name="Record set for world’s longest dragon boat"/>

This '''list of DNS record types''' is an overview of [[resource record]]s (RRs) permissible in [[zone file]]s of the [[Domain Name System]] (DNS). It also contains pseudo-RRs. ==Resource records== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Type ! Type id. (decimal) ! width="90pt"|Defining RFC ! Description ! Function |- |
A |1 |RFC 1035 {{cite web | title = RFC 1035: Domain Names - Implementation and Specification | publisher = Network Working Group of the IETF ([[Internet Engineering Task Force]]) | author = Paul Mockapetris | authorlink = Paul Mockapetris | page = 12 | date = November 1987 | url = http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1035#page-12 }} | Address record|| Returns a 32-bit [[IPv4]] address, most commonly used to map [[hostname]]s to an IP address of the host, but it is also used for [[DNSBL]]s, storing [[subnet mask]]s in RFC 1101, etc. |- |
[[AAAA record|AAAA]] |28 |RFC 3596 {{cite web | url = http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3596#section-2 | title = RFC 3596: DNS Extensions to Support IP Version 6 | publisher = [[The Internet Society]] | date = October 2003 }} | [[IPv6]] address record|| Returns a 128-bit [[IPv6]] address, most commonly used to map [[hostname]]s to an IP address of the host. |- |
AFSDB |18 |RFC 1183 |AFS database record |Location of database servers of an [[Andrew File System|AFS]] cell. This record is commonly used by AFS clients to contact AFS cells outside their local domain. A subtype of this record is used by the obsolete [[DCE Distributed File System|DCE/DFS]] file system. |- |
APL |42 |RFC 3123 |Address Prefix List |Specify lists of address ranges, e.g. in [[CIDR]] format, for various address families. Experimental. |- |
[[CAA record|CAA]] |257 |RFC 6844 |Certification Authority Authorization |[[DNS Certification Authority Authorization]], constraining acceptable CAs for a host/domain |- |
CDNSKEY |60 |RFC 7344 | |Child copy of DNSKEY record, for transfer to parent |- |
CDS |59 |RFC 7344 |Child DS |Child copy of DS record, for transfer to parent |- |
CERT ||37||RFC 4398||Certificate record||Stores [[PKIX]], [[SPKI]], [[Pretty Good Privacy|PGP]], etc. |- | [[CNAME record|CNAME]] |5 |[http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1035#page-12 RFC 1035] | [[Canonical name record]]|| Alias of one name to another: the DNS lookup will continue by retrying the lookup with the new name. |- |
DHCID ||49||RFC 4701||DHCP identifier||Used in conjunction with the FQDN option to [[DHCP]] |- |
DLV||32769||RFC 4431||DNSSEC Lookaside Validation record||For publishing [[DNSSEC]] trust anchors outside of the DNS delegation chain. Uses the same format as the DS record. RFC 5074 describes a way of using these records. |- |
[[DNAME record|DNAME]] |39 |RFC 6672 | |Alias for a name and all its subnames, unlike CNAME, which is an alias for only the exact name. Like a CNAME record, the DNS lookup will continue by retrying the lookup with the new name. |- |
DNSKEY||48||RFC 4034||DNS Key record||The key record used in [[DNSSEC]]. Uses the same format as the KEY record. |- |
DS||43||RFC 4034||Delegation signer||The record used to identify the DNSSEC signing key of a delegated zone |- |
[[Host Identity Protocol|HIP]] |55 |RFC 8005 |[[Host Identity Protocol]] |Method of separating the end-point identifier and locator roles of IP addresses. |- |
IPSECKEY||45||RFC 4025||IPsec Key||Key record that can be used with [[IPsec]] |- |
KEY||25||RFC 2535RFC 2535, §3 and RFC 2930RFC 3445, §1. "The KEY RR was defined in RFC 2930..."||Key record||Used only for SIG(0) (RFC 2931) and TKEY (RFC 2930).RFC 2931, §2.4. "SIG(0) on the other hand, uses public key authentication, where the public keys are stored in DNS as KEY RRs and a private key is stored at the signer." RFC 3445 eliminated their use for application keys and limited their use to DNSSEC.RFC 3445, §1. "DNSSEC will be the only allowable sub-type for the KEY RR..." RFC 3755 designates DNSKEY as the replacement within DNSSEC.RFC 3755, §3. "DNSKEY will be the replacement for KEY, with the mnemonic indicating that these keys are not for application use, per RFC3445. RRSIG (Resource Record SIGnature) will replace SIG, and NSEC (Next SECure) will replace NXT. These new types completely replace the old types, except that SIG(0) RFC2931 and TKEY RFC2930 will continue to use SIG and KEY." RFC 4025 designates IPSECKEY as the replacement for use with IPsec.RFC 4025, Abstract. "This record replaces the functionality of the sub-type #4 of the KEY Resource Record, which has been obsoleted by RFC 3445." |- |
KX |36 |RFC 2230 | Key Exchanger record | Used with some cryptographic systems (not including DNSSEC) to identify a key management agent for the associated domain-name. Note that this has nothing to do with DNS Security. It is Informational status, rather than being on the IETF standards-track. It has always had limited deployment, but is still in use. |- | [[LOC record|LOC]] |29 |RFC 1876 | Location record | Specifies a geographical location associated with a domain name |- | [[MX record|MX]] |15 |[http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1035#page-12 RFC 1035] and RFC 7505 | Mail exchange record | Maps a domain name to a list of [[message transfer agent]]s for that domain |- | [[NAPTR record|NAPTR]] |35 |RFC 3403 | Naming Authority Pointer | Allows regular-expression-based rewriting of domain names which can then be used as [[URI]]s, further domain names to lookups, etc. |- |
NS |2 |[http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1035#page-12 RFC 1035] | Name server record | Delegates a [[DNS zone]] to use the given [[authoritative name server]]s |- |
NSEC||47||RFC 4034||Next Secure record||Part of DNSSEC—used to prove a name does not exist. Uses the same format as the (obsolete) NXT record. |- |
NSEC3||50||RFC 5155||Next Secure record version 3||An extension to DNSSEC that allows proof of nonexistence for a name without permitting zonewalking |- |
NSEC3PARAM||51||RFC 5155||NSEC3 parameters||Parameter record for use with NSEC3 |- |OPENPGPKEY |61 |RFC 7929 |OpenPGP public key record |A [[DNS-based Authentication of Named Entities]] (DANE) method for publishing and locating OpenPGP public keys in DNS for a specific email address using an OPENPGPKEY DNS resource record. |- |
PTR |12 |[http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1035#page-12 RFC 1035] | Pointer record | Pointer to a [[canonical name]]. Unlike a CNAME, DNS processing stops and just the name is returned. The most common use is for implementing [[reverse DNS lookup]]s, but other uses include such things as [[Zero configuration networking#Apple's protocol: Multicast DNS/DNS-SD|DNS-SD]]. |- |
RRSIG||46||RFC 4034||DNSSEC signature||Signature for a DNSSEC-secured record set. Uses the same format as the SIG record. |- |
RP||17||RFC 1183||Responsible Person||Information about the responsible person(s) for the domain. Usually an email address with the @ replaced by a . |- |
SIG||24||RFC 2535||Signature||Signature record used in SIG(0) (RFC 2931) and TKEY (RFC 2930). RFC 3755 designated RRSIG as the replacement for SIG for use within DNSSEC. |- id="SMIMEA" | SMIMEA | 53 | RFC 8162{{cite web | url = https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8162#section-2 | title = RFC 8162 - Using Secure DNS to Associate Certificates with Domain Names for S/MIME | publisher = [[Internet Engineering Task Force]] | date = May 2017 | accessdate = 17 October 2018}} | S/MIME cert association{{cite web | url = https://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-parameters/dns-parameters.xhtml | title = Domain Name System (DNS) Parameters | publisher = [[Internet Assigned Numbers Authority]] | date = September 2018 | accessdate = 17 October 2018}} | Associates an S/MIME certificate with a domain name for sender authentication. |- id="SOA" | [[SOA record|SOA]] | 6 | [http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1035#page-12 RFC 1035] and RFC 2308The minimum field of SOA record is redefined to be the TTL of NXDOMAIN reply in RFC 2308. | Start of [a zone of] authority record | Specifies ''authoritative'' information about a [[DNS zone]], including the primary name server, the email of the domain administrator, the domain serial number, and several timers relating to refreshing the zone. |- | [[SRV record|SRV]] |33 |RFC 2782 |Service locator |Generalized service location record, used for newer protocols instead of creating protocol-specific records such as MX. |- |
[[SSHFP record|SSHFP]] |44 |RFC 4255 |SSH Public Key Fingerprint |Resource record for publishing [[Secure Shell|SSH]] public host key fingerprints in the DNS System, in order to aid in verifying the authenticity of the host. RFC 6594 defines ECC SSH keys and SHA-256 hashes. See the [http://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-sshfp-rr-parameters/dns-sshfp-rr-parameters.xml IANA SSHFP RR parameters registry] for details. |- |
TA||32768||{{n/a}}||DNSSEC Trust Authorities||Part of a deployment proposal for DNSSEC without a signed DNS root. See the [http://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-parameters IANA database] and [http://www.watson.org/~weiler/INI1999-19.pdf Weiler Spec] for details. Uses the same format as the DS record. |- |
[[TKEY record|TKEY]] |249 |RFC 2930 |Transaction Key record |A method of providing keying material to be used with [[TSIG]] that is encrypted under the public key in an accompanying KEY RR.RFC 2930, §6. "... the keying material is sent within the key data field of a TKEY RR encrypted under the public key in an accompanying KEY RR RFC 2535." |- |
[[TLSA]] |52 |RFC 6698 |TLSA certificate association |A record for [[DNS-based Authentication of Named Entities|DANE]]. RFC 6698 defines "The TLSA DNS resource record is used to associate a TLS server certificate or public key with the domain name where the record is found, thus forming a 'TLSA certificate association'". |- |
[[TSIG]] |250 |RFC 2845 |Transaction Signature |Can be used to authenticate [[dynamic DNS|dynamic updates]] as coming from an approved client, or to authenticate responses as coming from an approved recursive name serverRFC 2845, abstract similar to DNSSEC. |- |
[[TXT record|TXT]] |16 |[http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1035#page-12 RFC 1035] |Text record |Originally for arbitrary human-readable ''text'' in a DNS record. Since the early 1990s, however, this record more often carries [[machine-readable data]], such as specified by RFC 1464, [[opportunistic encryption]], [[Sender Policy Framework]], [[DKIM]], [[DMARC]], [[Zero configuration networking#Apple's multicast DNS/DNS-SD|DNS-SD]], etc. |- |
[[URI record|URI]] |256 |RFC 7553 |Uniform Resource Identifier |Can be used for publishing mappings from hostnames to URIs. |} ==Other types and pseudo resource records== Other types of records simply provide some types of information (for example, an HINFO record gives a description of the type of computer/OS a host uses), or others return data used in experimental features. The "type" field is also used in the protocol for various operations. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! | Type ! | Type id. ! width="90pt" | Defining RFC ! class="unsortable" | Description ! class="unsortable" | Function |-f |* |255 |[http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1035#page-12 RFC 1035] |All cached records |Returns all records of all types known to the name server. If the name server does not have any information on the name, the request will be forwarded on. The records returned may not be complete. For example, if there is both an A and an MX for a name, but the name server has only the A record cached, only the A record will be returned. Sometimes referred to as "ANY", for example in Windows nslookup and Wireshark. |- |[[AXFR]] |252 |[http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1035#page-12 RFC 1035] | Authoritative Zone Transfer |Transfer entire zone file from the master name server to secondary name servers. |- |
IXFR |251 |RFC 1996 | Incremental Zone Transfer|| Requests a zone transfer of the given zone but only differences from a previous serial number. This request may be ignored and a full (AXFR) sent in response if the authoritative server is unable to fulfill the request due to configuration or lack of required deltas. |- |
OPT |41 |RFC 6891 |Option |This is a "pseudo DNS record type" needed to support [[EDNS]] |} ==Obsolete record types== Progress has rendered some of the originally defined record-types obsolete. Of the records listed at IANA, some have limited use, for various reasons. Some are marked obsolete in the list, some are for very obscure services, some are for older versions of services, and some have special notes saying they are "not right". {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! | Type ! | Type id. ! width="90pt" | Defining RFC !Obsoleted by ! class="unsortable" |Description |- f |MD MF MAILA |3 4 254 |RFC 883 |RFC 973 |Mail destination (MD) and mail forwarder (MF) records; MAILA is not an actual record type, but a query type which returns MF and/or MD records. RFC 973 replaced these records with the MX record. |- |MB MG MR MINFO MAILB |7 8 9 14 253 |RFC 883 |Not formally obsoleted. Unlikely to be ever adopted (RFC 2505). |Records to publish mailing list subscriber lists in the DNS: MB(7), MG(8), MR(9), MINFO(14); MAILB (253) is a query code which returns one of the aforementioned records. The intent, as specified by RFC 883, was for MB to replace the [[SMTP]] VRFY command, MG to replace the SMTP EXPN command, and MR to replace the "551 User Not Local" SMTP error. Later, RFC 2505 recommended that both the VRFY and EXPN commands be disabled, making the use of MB and MG unlikely to ever be adopted. They were classified as experimental by RFC 1035. |- |WKS |11 |RFC 883, RFC 1035 |Declared as "not to be relied upon" by RFC 1123 (with further information in RFC 1127): WKS(11)RFC 1123 section 2.2, 5.2.12, 6.1.3.6 |Record to describe well-known services supported by a host. Not used in practice. The current recommendation and practice is to determine whether a service is supported on an IP address by trying to connect to it. SMTP is even prohibited from using WKS records in MX processing. |- |NB NBSTAT |32 33 |RFC 1002 | |Mistakes: NB(32), NBSTAT(33) (from RFC 1002); the numbers are now assigned to NIMLOC and SRV. |- |NULL |10 |RFC 883 |RFC 1035 |Obsoleted by RFC 1035: NULL(10) (RFC 883 defined "completion queries" (opcode 2 and maybe 3) which used this record, RFC 1035 later reassigned opcode 2 to be "status" and reserved opcode 3.) |- |A6 |38 |RFC 2874 |RFC 6563 |Defined as part of early IPv6 but downgraded to experimental by RFC 3363: A6(38), Later downgraded to historic in RFC 6563. |- |
NXT KEY SIG |30 25 24 |RFC 2065 |RFC 3755 |Part of the first version of DNSSEC (RFC 2065). Obsoleted by DNSSEC updates (RFC 3755): NXT(30). At the same time, the domain of applicability for KEY and SIG was also limited to not include DNSSEC use. |- |HINFO |13 |RFC 883 |Not obsoleted. Currently used by [[Cloudflare]] in response to queries of the type ANY(255) [https://blog.cloudflare.com/what-happened-next-the-deprecation-of-any/] |Record intended to provide information about host CPU type and operating system. It was intended to allow protocols to optimize processing when communicating with similar peers |- |RP |17 | | |RP may be used for certain human-readable information regarding a different contact point for a specific host, subnet, or other domain level label separate than that used in the SOA record. |- |X25 |19 | | |Not in current use by any notable application |- |ISDN RT NSAP |20 21 22 | | |Not in current use by any notable application |- |NSAP-PTR PX EID |23 26 31 | | |Not in current use by any notable application |- |NIMLOC ATMA APL |32 34 42 | | |Not in current use by any notable application |- |SINK |40 | | |Defined by the [http://www.tools.ietf.org/html/draft-eastlake-kitchen-sink Kitchen Sink] [[internet draft]], but never made it to RFC status: SINK(40) |- |GPOS |27 | | |A more limited early version of the LOC record: GPOS(27) |- |UINFO UID GID UNSPEC |100 101 102 103 | | |IANA reserved, no RFC documented them [https://web.archive.org/web/20080611185015/http://www.ops.ietf.org/lists/namedroppers/namedroppers.2004/msg00949.html] and support was removed from [[BIND]] in the early 90s: UINFO(100), UID(101), GID(102), UNSPEC(103) |- |[[Sender Policy Framework|SPF]] |99 |RFC 4408 |RFC 7208 |[[Sender Policy Framework|SPF]](99) (from RFC 4408) was specified as part of the [[Sender Policy Framework]] protocol as an alternative to storing SPF data in TXT records, using the same format. It was later found that the majority of SPF deployments lack proper support for this record type, and support for it was discontinued in RFC 7208.{{cite IETF|title=Resolution of the Sender Policy Framework (SPF) and Sender ID Experiments|rfc=6686|appendix=A|sectionname=Background on the RRTYPE Issue|first1=M.|last1=Kucherawy|year=2012|month=July|publisher=[[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]]|accessdate=August 31, 2013}} {{cite IETF|title=Sender Policy Framework (SPF) for Authorizing Use of Domains in Email, Version 1|rfc=7208|section=3.1|sectionname=The SPF DNS Record Type|first1=S.|last1=Kitterman|date=April, 2014|publisher=[[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]]|accessdate=26 April 2014}} |} ==Further reading== * {{cite web|url=https://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-parameters/dns-parameters.xhtml|title=Domain Name System (DNS) Parameters|accessdate=2018-08-14}} * {{cite web|url=https://support.google.com/a/answer/48090|title=DNS basics - G Suite Administrator Help|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2018-11-08}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Domain name system]] [[Category:Internet protocols]] [[Category:DNS record types| ]]

revision.text:
[[File:Wayne-Thiebaud---De-Young-1 label.jpg|thumb||An object label at the [[de Young Museum]]]] {{globalize|date=July 2018}} A '''museum label''' or caption is a [[label]] describing an object exhibited in a [[museum]] or one introducing a room or area.<ref Name="objectlabels">[http://www.museumprofessionals.org/forum/member-articles/2424-writing-exhibit-labels.html Writing Exhibit Labels / object labels] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430212508/http://www.museumprofessionals.org/forum/member-articles/2424-writing-exhibit-labels.html |date=2011-04-30 }}</ref><ref Name="EnduringLabel">[http://www.archimuse.com/mw2007/papers/parry/parry.html The Enduring Label — How Shall We Label Our Exhibit Today? Applying the Principles of On-Line Publishing to an On-Site Exhibition]</ref>
==Description of various museum labels== ===Introduction labels=== Kim Kenney, curator of the [[William McKinley Presidential Library and Museum]] says that the first label a visitor should see should explain your exhibit display in general. The introduction label should be a “teaser” and talk about the main sections of your exhibit to encourage people to see the rest. If there is something significant or special of the main exhibit, it should be introduced here. At this point the visitor should have a good feeling what the museum is generally about. Visitors should understand immediately what they are going to see and they should desire to want to see the entire exhibit. Perhaps a brochure would accompany the introduction explaining the main museum, the price, and the hours.<ref Name="objectlabels"/>
=== Section labels === A section label is a small introduction. It consists of sub-topics in a museum exhibition. Kenney says they should represent the "meat" of the museum. If the section is large, perhaps more than one section label is in order. The description should consist of 100-200 words or thereabouts. The visitor should not be strained to read all the labels, so they should be on the short side if anything.<ref Name="objectlabels"/>
===Object labels=== [[File:Wayne-Thiebaud---De-Young-1 label.jpg|thumb||An object label at the [[de Young Museum]]]] [[File:Thomas Cole NHS 34.jpg|thumb|upright=0.8|A decorative museum label at the [[Thomas Cole National Historic Site]]]] Object labels are the smallest. They just describe the individual object they are displayed next to. Typically the title of the work or a descriptive title phrase is given, followed by the date and place of creation, and the materials or technique of the object. Increasingly, there may be a brief description or commentary. An accession number is often given, and often the accession date. If the object is included in an [[audio guide]] or some other form of tour, there may be a symbol indicating this. Kenney says she prefers in an object label a one word title followed by a 25–50 word description for a museum label. She explains that people want specific aspects of the object they might not notice at first glance or might not have already known (i.e. something unusual, material made of, date of artifact, who made). Most people want to know specifics like when it was made, why it was made, usage and when it became part of the museum.<ref Name="objectlabels"/>
===Credit panel=== Practice varies as to whether accession dates and donor information are included. Some donations, especially from government organizations, may specify a credit on the label. Loaned objects are usually specified in some way. It is the opinion of Kenney that donor information clutters up the object label. She believes it is better to give a list of donors on a credit panel.<ref Name="objectlabels"/>
==History== [[File:Belshalti-nannar's museum label.jpg|thumb|upright|The first known museum label]] The first known museum labels are from the [[Ennigaldi-Nanna's museum]] originally dating to circa 530 BCE.<ref>Woolley, ''Excavations at Ur: a record of twelve years' work.'', p. 238 ''The room was a museum of local antiquities maintained by the princess Belshalti-Nannar, and in the collection was this clay drum, the earliest museum label known...''</ref><ref Name="Casey">Casey, p. "First Public Museum" ''Around 530 B.C.E. in Ur, an educational museum containing a collection of labeled antiquities was founded by Ennigaldi-Nannathe, daughter of Nabonidus, the last king of Babylonia.''</ref>
The museum labels of the 20th century and 21st century BCE items found in Ennigaldi's museum were labeled in three different languages on clay cylinders as to what the centuries old objects were.<ref>[http://www.uv.es/EBRIT/macro/macro_5004_43_1.html THE PRECURSORS OF MUSEUMS]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>Leon, p. 36 ''When archaeologists excavated certain parts of the palace and temple complex at Ur, they were puzzled to find dozens of artifacts, neatly arranged side by side whose ages varied by hundreds of years. Then clay drums with labels in three languages showed up — the first known museum labels.''</ref><ref Name="Woolley">Woolley, ''Ur of the Chaldees'' pp. 252–259</ref>
Some of these artifacts were: * a [[kudurru]], Kassite boundary marker (carved with a snake and emblems of various gods). * part of a statue of King [[Shulgi]]. * clay cone that was part of a building at [[Larsa]].<ref Name="Casey"/>
Museum-like behavior occurred as early as the 19th-century BCE which gave indications of steps of labeling and cataloging antiquities.<ref Name="Woolley236">Woolley, Excavations at Ur: a record of twelve years' work., p. 236</ref><ref>[http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0014/001410/141067e.pdf The Role of Museums and the Professional Code of Ethics], p. 1</ref> A "museum label" cylinder tablet describing 100-year-old antiquity objects of circa 2000 BCE read,{{cquote|These are copies from bricks found in the ruins of Ur, the work of [[Bur-Sin]] of Ur, which while searching for the groundplan (of the temple) the Governor of Ur found, and I saw and wrote out for the marvel of the beholder.''<ref Name="Woolley236"/><ref>[http://www.nyu.edu/alumni.magazine/issue14/14_feature_montebello.html Former Met director—and first-time professor—Philippe de Montebello takes the podium to explain how collectors have anointed “art” through the ages] '' An excavation at the ancient Sumerian city of Ur, in modern-day Iraq, found what is considered the oldest museum label: a 19th-century BCE tablet describing an object, then 100 years old, presented, as it read, “...for the marvel of the beholder.”''</ref> }}
==Future== There are studies recently done that demonstrate the feasibility of a wireless Web-based tool for an in-gallery paperless digital label system, perhaps in the form of "Digital Label Towers" or wall mounted digital displays. Some concepts that could be used then is changing configurations of the museum labels, digitally updating the electronic museum label, usability on various display systems, and integrate third party content.<ref Name="EnduringLabel"/>
Other advanced digital technology used by some museums is the use of [[barcode]]s on their museum labels.<ref>[http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0014/001410/141067e.pdf Running a Museum: A Practical Handbook], p. 30 describes bar codes in "museum labels".</ref>
==References== {{Commons category|Museum labels}} {{reflist}}
==Sources== *Casey, Wilson, ''Firsts: Origins of Everyday Things That Changed the World'', Penguin, 2009, {{ISBN|1-59257-924-8}}. *León, Vicki, ''Uppity women of ancient times'', Conari Press, 1995, {{ISBN|1-57324-010-9}}. *Woolley, Leonard, ''Ur "of the Chaldees": the final account, Excavations at Ur'', Herbert Press, 1982, {{ISBN|0-906969-21-2}}. *Woolley, Leonard, ''Excavations at Ur — A Record of Twelve Years Work by Sir Leonard Woolley'', Ernest Benn Limited, 1955, printed in Great Britain.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Museum label}}
[[Category:Museum education|Label]] [[Category:Museology]]

{{infobox software | name = OpenDJ | logo = OpenDJ Logo.svg | screenshot = OpenDJ2.4ControlPanel.png | caption = OpenDJ 2.4 Control Panel | released = {{release date|mf=yes|2010|12|21}} | latest release version = Release 4.2.2 <ref>{{cite web|url=https://github.com/OpenIdentityPlatform/OpenDJ/releases|title=OpenDJ Downloads}}</ref> | latest release date = {{release date|mf=yes|2018|10|08}} | operating system = Linux, Windows, MacOS, Solaris, AIX | platform = [[Java (software platform)|Java]] | programming language = [[Java (programming language)|Java]] | language = English, French, German, Japanese, Simplified Chinese, Spanish | genre = [[Directory service]] | license = [[Common Development and Distribution License|CDDL]] | website = {{URL|https://github.com/OpenIdentityPlatform/OpenDJ/}} }}
'''OpenDJ''' is a [[directory server]] which implements a wide range of [[Lightweight Directory Access Protocol]] and related standards, including full compliance with LDAPv3 but also support for [[Directory Service Markup Language]] (DSMLv2).<ref name=ForgeRock>{{cite web|title=OpenDJ|url=http://forgerock.com/products/open-identity-stack/opendj/|accessdate=2014-05-28}}</ref> Written in [[Java (programming language)|Java]], OpenDJ offers [[multi-master replication]], access control, and many extensions.
OpenDJ began as a [[Fork (software development)|fork]] of '''OpenDS''', an LDAP / DSML server which originated in 2005 as an internal project at [[Sun Microsystems]] started by Neil A. Wilson, and later grew into an open source project, maintained by [[Oracle Corporation]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://java.net/projects/opends|title=Opends — Project Kenai|accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> following Oracle's acquisition of Sun, OpenDJ is the main trunk developed [[ForgeRock]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forgerock.com/opendj.html|title=OpenDJ|accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> and maintained by [[Open Identity Platform Community]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://github.com/OpenIdentityPlatform|title=Open Identity Platform Community}}</ref>. OpenDJ source code<ref>{{cite web|url=https://github.com/OpenIdentityPlatform/OpenDJ|title=OpenDJ Source code}}</ref> and binary distribution<ref>{{cite web|url=https://github.com/OpenIdentityPlatform/OpenDJ/releases|title=OpenDJ Releases}}</ref> are available under the [[Common Development and Distribution License]] (CDDL).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://github.com/OpenIdentityPlatform/OpenDJ/blob/master/LICENSE.md|title=OpenDJ License}}</ref>
== History ==
The work on OpenDS started as an internal Sun project around February 2005. OpenDS was initially developed primarily by Neil A. Wilson. Wilson was joined by a small team of engineers from Sun's Directory Server team. The code was open-sourced in June 2006.
Sun increased the number of developers working on OpenDS technology after open-sourcing the code. Developers outside Sun also joined the new open-source project. Community members like Boni.org, Penrose, and JBoss began to use OpenDS in their projects. In early 2008 the OpenDS project had over 20 regular contributors.
In April 2007, the project owners modified the project governance. The text "This Project Lead, who is appointed by Sun Microsystems, is responsible for managing the entire project" was replaced by "This Project Lead, who is appointed and removed by a majority vote of the Project Owners, is responsible for managing the entire project".
In September 2007, the project owners were laid off from Sun Microsystems.
Late in 2007, questions arose as to whether the project was governed as an open source project. One of the project owners complained publicly that Sun Microsystems had required project owners to accept governance changes to the project in order to keep their benefits.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://directorymanager.wordpress.com/2007/11/28/an-open-letter-to-the-opends-community-and-to-sun-microsystems |title=An Open Letter to the OpenDS Community and to Sun Microsystems |accessdate=2016-08-30 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327142954/http://directorymanager.wordpress.com/2007/11/28/an-open-letter-to-the-opends-community-and-to-sun-microsystems |archivedate=March 27, 2009 |df= }}</ref> The team resigned from their project owner role. [[Simon Phipps (programmer)|Simon Phipps]], Chief Open source Officer of Sun Microsystems, claimed that Sun was only reverting governance changes that had never been approved. John Waters also published an article on the topic.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2007/12/05/sun_opends_defining_terms/|title=Winners and losers in Sun's OpenDS spat|first1=Social networks talk hidden|last1=architectures|first2=you reeled: the year's most overused phrases|last2=They used 'em|first3=Tips from the top: cracking Christmas and New-Year|last3=books|publisher=}}</ref>
OpenDJ began after the acquisition of Sun Microsystems by Oracle. At that time, Oracle announced that Sun OpenDS Standard Edition was not seen as a strategic product,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oracle.com.edgesuite.net/ivt/4000/8104/9236/12628/lobby_external_flash_clean_480x360/default.htm|title=Oracle + Sun: Identity Management Strategy (webcast)|format=Flash|at=around 8:30|accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref> although the investment on the OpenDS source code would continue. Sun had supported commercial versions of Sun OpenDS Standard Edition since version 1.0 in 2008.
Mid-September 2010, Ludovic Poitou, then OpenDS community leader and co-project owner, left Oracle for [[ForgeRock]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.sun.com/Ludo/entry/moving_on|title=Moving on... - Ludo's Sketches|accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref>
In October 2010, Oracle provided an OpenDS 2.2.1 update to the community with several fixes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opends.org/|title=OpenDS : the Open Source Java LDAP Directory Service|accessdate=2011-02-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070608092650/http://opends.org/|archivedate=2007-06-08|df=}}</ref>
In December 2010, ForgeRock released OpenDJ 2.4.0 including fixes and support for new features like Collective Attributes, Microsoft Active Directory Permissive Modification Control, and multiple objectclass inheritance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jaxenter.com/icefaces-2-0-0-and-opendj-2-4-0-released-33160.html|title=IceFaces 2.0.0 and OpenDJ 2.4.0 Released|accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref>
In late January 2011 Matthew Swift, previously "responsible for the core server" of the OpenDS project joined ForgeRock to work on OpenDJ as product architect.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://webmink.com/2011/01/31/new-opendj-architect/|title=New OpenDJ Architect « Wild Webmink|accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> Starting in mid-February 2011, ForgeRock began to build an "OpenDJ product suite, comprising an open source LDAP Directory Server, client tools, and LDAP SDK" as a [[Apache Maven|Maven]] project,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sources.forgerock.org/browse/opendj/trunk/opendj3/README?r=HEAD|title=FishEye: Annotated - opendj/trunk/opendj3/README|accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> with the tools and SDK modules appearing first.
In 2011, a few months after the acquisition of [[Sun Microsystems]], [[Oracle Corporation|Oracle]] released [[Oracle Unified Directory]], based on OpenDS.
ForgeRock posted an OpenDJ roadmap through release 4, targeted for 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wikis.forgerock.org/confluence/display/OPENDJ/OpenDJ+Roadmap|title=OpenDJ Roadmap - OpenDJ - Confluence|accessdate=2014-05-14}}</ref>
Since November 2016, ForgeRock closed OpenDJ source code, renamed OpenDJ to [[Forgerock Directory Services]] and started to distribute it under commercial license.<ref name=":1">{{cite web | title=ForgeRock has shuttered the open-source community, and no longer allows new development on their platform under a permissive license | website=timeforafork | date=June 1, 2017 | url=http://www.timeforafork.com/ | ref={{sfnref | ForgeRock | 2017}} | accessdate=June 1, 2017}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |+ Release history ! Date ! Release |- | December 15, 2009 | OpenDS 2.2.0<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opends.org/promoted-builds/2.2.0|title=— Project Kenai|publisher=}}</ref> |- | July 17, 2009 | OpenDS 2.0.0<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opends.org/promoted-builds/2.0.0|title=— Project Kenai|publisher=}}</ref> |- | July 3, 2009 | OpenDS 2.0.0 RC4<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opends.org/promoted-builds/2.0.0-RC4|title=— Project Kenai|publisher=}}</ref> |- | June 23, 2009 | OpenDS 2.0.0 RC3<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opends.org/promoted-builds/2.0.0-RC3|title=— Project Kenai|publisher=}}</ref> |- | June 10, 2009 | OpenDS 2.0.0 RC2<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opends.org/promoted-builds/2.0.0-RC2|title=— Project Kenai|publisher=}}</ref> |- | May 25, 2009 | OpenDS 2.0.0 RC1<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opends.org/promoted-builds/2.0.0-RC1|title=— Project Kenai|publisher=}}</ref> |- | October 6, 2010 | OpenDS 2.2 Update 1 |- | October 6, 2010 | OpenDS 2.2 Update 1 |- | October 8, 2018 | OpenDJ Community 4.2.2 with JDK11 support |}
OpenDJ 2.4, released December 2010, provided improvements corresponding to many of those defined, but not yet scheduled for OpenDS 2.4<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.opends.org/wiki/page/OpenDSRoadmap|title=OpenDS Wiki: Open DS Roadmap|accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref>
OpenDJ 2.6, released June 2013, provided a REST to LDAP interface allowing easy and secure access to the data, also eased integration with other services, provided native packages for Linux, and the LDAP client SDK.
The latest Forgerock release of OpenDJ is 3.0.0.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://docs.forgerock.org/en/index.html?product=opendj|title=ForgeRock BackStage|first=|last=ForgeRock|publisher=}}</ref>
OpenDJ 3.0 is expected to include directory proxy services, but the support for LDAP Transactions that was originally planned was dropped due to the incompatibility with the loose consistency model of LDAP.
OpenDJ 3.1 and 3.2 are slated to include enhanced directory proxy services.
OpenDJ 4.1.4 resumed to maintain by [[Open Identity Platform Community]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://github.com/OpenIdentityPlatform|title=Open Identity Platform Community}}</ref> and issued new release: <ref>{{cite web|url=https://github.com/OpenIdentityPlatform/OpenDJ/releases|title=OpenDJ Downloads}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Pierre-Ange Vieillard de Boismartin | birth_date = 17 June 1778 | birth_place = [[Rouen]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1862|01|12|1778|06|17}} | death_place = [[Paris]] | othername = | occupation = Playwright
Librettist | years_active = | spouse = Anaïs-Henriette Formey Saint-Louvent | signature = }} '''Pierre-Ange Vieillard de Boismartin''' (17 June 1778 – 12 January 1862) was a 19th-century French poet, playwright and literary critic. == Biography == Vieillard was the son of [[Antoine Vieillard de Boismartin]], a lawyer at the [[Parlement]] of Rouen, then mayor of [[Saint-Lô]], known for his beautiful and generous defense of the Verdure family (1780-1789), earning him the direct praise of [[Louis XVI of France|Louis XVI]], to whom he was introduced, and a kind of civic ovation in the midst of the [[National Constituent Assembly (France)|National Constituent Assembly]], during the session of January 30, 1790. A payor at the Treasure (1806), Royal censor (1820-1824), director of the mayors' newspaper (1822-1824), literary critic by the ''[[Le Moniteur Universel|Moniteur universel et officiel]]'', director and chief curator of the [[bibliothèque de l'Arsenal]], then librarian at the [[Senate (France)|Senate]] in 1854, where he succeeded [[Paul-Mathieu Laurent]], Vieillard began early in the dramatic career. He produced no less than 30 plays, 24 of which were presented in different theaters, such as the [[Paris Opéra|Opéra]], the [[Opéra-Comique]], the [[Théâtre-Français]] and the [[Théâtre du Vaudeville]]. The verve he spent in these various works, where he worked with [[Armand Gouffé]], [[Georges Duval]], [[René de Chazet]], [[Théophile Marion Dumersan|Dumersan]], Jules Merle and [[Joseph Pain]], did not prevent him to exploit the [[literary criticism]] which asked for more seriousness and a more complete maturity of mind on his part. Vieillard published in several newspapers, mainly in the former ''Moniteur universel'', many articles that reflected the breadth and variety of his knowledge. He also became one of the principal editors of the ''Encyclopédie des gens du monde'', where he was specially commissioned to write biographies about famous men of the French Revolution. Well versed in the history of that time, which he lived, the moderation of his opinions and the uprightness of his character let him naturally assess accurately the events and actors. Thus he could believe he was authorized to contribute the ''[[Le Moniteur Universel]]'' a series of studies on the ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Histoire des Girondins|fr|3=Histoire des Girondins|lt=Girondins}}'' by [[Alphonse de Lamartine|Lamartine]], a work interrupted by the [[French Revolution of 1848|Revolution of 1848]]. Vieillard also had in the highest degree a feeling for music ; the last pamphlets he published in 1855 at the age of 78, testify of the passion of this dilettante. ''[[Étienne Nicolas Méhul|Méhul]]'', ''Madame Scio'', ''Vicissitudes d’un librettiste de l’ancien opéra'' are the titles of these curious and interesting studies reproduced by ''le Ménestrel''. Vieillard was particularly clever at finding a musical theme in a dramatic situation or a legend. At various occasions, the [[Académie des beaux-arts (France)|Académie des beaux-arts]] asked him seven [[cantata]]s. Only one was crowned and executed at the solemn session of the prize at the [[Institut de France|Institut]] in 1845. This time, the poet and the musician had drawn their inspirations in the ballad of Imogine, borrowed from ''[[the Monk]]'' by [[Matthew Gregory Lewis]]. Vieillard married Anaïs-Henriette Formey Saint-Louvent (16 February 1802, Saint-Lô – 16 November 1873, Versailles) 29 March 1826. He was made a chevalier of the [[Decoration of The Lily|Order of The Lily]] in 1814 and of the [[Légion d'honneur|ordre royal de la Légion d'honneur]] in 1815, and was also a member of the [[Académie des Sciences, Arts et Belles-Lettres de Caen|académies de Caen]] and [[Société nationale académique de Cherbourg|Cherbourg]]. Vieillard signed his works under different forms of his name or initials and the [[pen name]]s '''Madame P.V. de L.B.''' et '''Jules'''.[http://catalogue.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/cb12240505q/PUBLIC Notice d'autorité personne de la BnF] == Main publications == ;Theatre *1800: ''Gilles ventriloque'', one-act [[Parade (French street entertainment)|parade]] mingled with vaudevilles, with Nicolas Gersin and [[Antoine Année]], [[Théâtre du Vaudeville]], 5 March [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5772166b.pdf Text online] *1800: ''Le Premier Homme du monde, ou la Création du sommeil'', one-act folie-vaudeville, with Antoine Année, Theatre of the [[Opéra-Comique]], 30 December *1802: ''Marmontel'', one-act comedy, in prose, mingled with vaudevilles, with Tournay and [[Armand Gouffé]], Vaudeville, 23 August *1803: ''Le Père d'occasion'', one-act comedy, in prose, with [[Joseph Pain]], [[Théâtre Louvois]], 25 January *1805: ''Les Travestissements'', comedy in 1 act and in prose, with Nicolas Gersin and Antoine Année, Louvois, 7 August *1806: ''Noir et blanc'', arlequinade, in 1 act and in vaudevilles, with [[Théophile Marion Dumersan]], Vaudeville, 24 May *1806: ''Brutal, ou Il vaut mieux tard que jamais'', [[comédie en vaudeville]] in 1 act and in prose, parody of ''Uthal'' by [[Jacques Bins, comte de Saint-Victor|Jacques Bins de Saint-Victor]], with Joseph-Marie Pain, Vaudeville, 31 May *1806: ''Chapelle et Bachaumont'', vaudeville anecdotique in 1 act, with [[Georges Duval]], [[Théâtre de l'Odéon|Montansier]], 30 August *1808: ''Le Retour au comptoir, ou l'Éducation déplacée'', one-act comédie en vaudeville, with Georges Duval, Vaudeville, 14 May *1809: ''Malherbe'', one-act comedy, mingled with vaudevilles, with Georges Duval, [[Théâtre des Variétés]], 27 May *1813: ''Les Rêveurs éveillés'', parade magnétique in 1 act, mingled with vaudevilles, with Joseph-Marie Pain, Vaudeville, 30 January *1816: ''Le Mariage de Robert de France, ou l'Astrologie en défaut'', one-act comedy in free verse, [[Comédie-Française|Théâtre-Français]], 22 June ;Varia *1802: ''La Boîte de Pandore et Vénus Callipyge'', tales in verse [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k54676923.pdf Text online] *1817: ''Poésies nationales'' *1819: ''Aux missionnaires de l'irréligion'' [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5467918k.pdf Text online] *1827: ''Époques mémorables de la révolution et de la Restauration'', mélanges en vers et en prose *1859: ''Souvenirs du théâtre. Méhul, sa vie et ses œuvres'' [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5628533k.pdf Text online] == References == {{Reflist}} == Sources == * Ferdinand Natanael Staaff, ''La Littérature française depuis la formation de la langue jusqu'à nos jours'', t. 2, Paris, Didier et Cie, 1878, (p. 1120-1122). == External links == * [http://data.bnf.fr/12240505/pierre-ange_vieillard/ Pierre-Ange Vieillard] on [[Data.bnf.fr]] {{Authority control}} {{Portal bar|theatre|Normandy}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vieillard de Boismartin, Pierre-Ange}} [[Category:19th-century French dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:French opera librettists]] [[Category:Writers from Normandy]] [[Category:French librarians]] [[Category:Encyclopedists]] [[Category:French literary critics]] [[Category:Chevaliers of the Légion d'honneur]] [[Category:People from Rouen]] [[Category:1778 births]] [[Category:1862 deaths]]

{{Communist Romania}} The '''Pitești Prison''' ({{lang-ro|Închisoarea Pitești}}) was a penal facility in [[Pitești]], [[Romania]], best remembered for the [[Mind control|reeducation]] experiments (also known as ''Experimentul Pitești'' – the "Pitești Experiment" or ''Fenomenul Pitești'' – the "Pitești Phenomenon") carried out between December 1949 and September 1951, during [[Romanian People's Republic|Communist party rule]]. The experiment, implemented by a group of prisoners under the guidance of the prison administration, was designed as an attempt at violently "reeducating" the mostly young [[political prisoner]]s, primarily supporters of the ultra-nationalist [[Iron Guard]], as well as former members of the [[National Peasants' Party|National Peasants']] and [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal]] parties or [[Zionism|Zionist]] members of the [[History of the Jews in Romania|Romanian Jewish community]].<ref>Cesereanu; Cioroianu, pp. 316–317; Rusan; Wexler</ref> Religious inmates also included Christian seminarians.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Black Book of Communism|last=Bartosek|first=Karel|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=1999|isbn=0-674-07608-7|location=Cambridge|pages=421|quote=|via=}}</ref> The experiment's goal was for prisoners to discard past political and religious convictions, and, eventually, to alter their [[Personality psychology|personalities]] to the point of absolute obedience.<ref name="Rusan">Rusan</ref> Estimates for the total number of people passed through the experiment range from up to 1,000<ref name="Rusan"/> to 5,000.<ref name="Popa">Popa</ref>
After the purging of Romanian leader [[Ana Pauker]], the experiment was halted as the Romanian communist regime was [[Romanianization|Romanianized]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The Rough Guide to Romania|isbn=9780241291610|page=87|quote=The experiment was abandoned in 1952, when the Stalinist leader Ana Pauker was purged}}</ref> The overseers were put under trial; while twenty of the participating prisoners were sentenced to death, prison officials were handed down light sentences.<ref name="Rusan"/>
Journalist and anti-communist activist [[Virgil Ierunca]] referred to the "reeducation experiment" as the largest and most intensive brainwashing torture program in the [[Eastern Bloc]].<ref>Ierunca, p. 41</ref> In even stronger terms, [[Nobel Laureate in Literature|Nobel Laureate]] and [[gulag]] survivor [[Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn|Alexander Solzhenitsyn]] called it "the most terrible act of barbarism in the contemporary world."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.agerpres.ro/english/2010/10/01/10th-edition-of-international-symposium-on-the-pitesti-experiment-re-education-through-torture-18-14-45|title=Agerpres|last=|first=|date=Oct 1, 2010|newspaper=|access-date=February 12, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|work=|agency=Romanian National News Agency|via=}}</ref>
==History==
===Beginnings=== The prison itself was built at an earlier stage. Work on it had begun in the late 1930s, under [[King of Romania|King]] [[Carol II of Romania|Carol II]], and had been completed during [[Ion Antonescu]]'s rule (''see [[Romania during World War II]]'').{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} The first political prisoners it housed arrived in 1942; these were high school students suspected of having taken part in the [[Legionnaires' rebellion and Bucharest pogrom|Legionnaires' rebellion]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Laurenţiu Ungureanu, [http://adevarul.ro/cultura/istorie/video-nicolae-purcareasupravietuitor-fenomenului-pitesti-victima-refuzat-devina-calau-marturii-despre-reeducarea-printortura-1_5145820900f5182b851a2806/index.html "Nicolae Purcărea, supravieţuitor al 'Fenomenului Piteşti'"], ''Adevărul'', March 17, 2013; accessed March 31, 2013</ref> For a while after the proclamation of a Romanian [[People's Republic]], it continued to house primarily those found guilty of [[misdemeanor]]s.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}}
Early attempts at "reeducation" had occurred at the prison in [[Suceava]], continuing in a violent manner in Pitești and, less violently, in [[Gherla prison]].<ref name="Rusan"/> The group of overseers had been formed from people who had themselves been arrested and found guilty of [[political crime]]s. Their leader, [[Eugen Țurcanu]], a prisoner and former member of the Iron Guard, who had also shortly joined the [[Romanian Communist Party|Communist Party]] before being purged, dissatisfied with the progress in Suceava, proposed using violent means in order to enhance the process, obtaining the agreement of the Pitești prison administration.<ref>Cioroianu, pp. 316–317</ref> Ţurcanu, who was probably acting on the orders of [[Securitate]] deputy chief [[Alexandru Nikolski]],<ref name="Cioroianu, p.317"/> selected a tight unit of reeducation survivors as his assistants in carrying out political tasks. This group was called the ''Organizaţia Deţinuţilor cu Convingeri Comuniste'' (ODCC, "Organization of Convinced Communist Detainees"),<ref name="Cioroianu, p.317">Cioroianu, p. 317</ref> and included the future [[Romanian Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] priest and [[dissident]] [[Gheorghe Calciu-Dumitreasa]] and the Jewish Petrică Fux.<ref>Wexler</ref>
===Stages of "reeducation"=== The process begun after that date involved [[psychological punishment]] (mainly through humiliation) and physical [[torture]].<ref>Cesereanu; Rusan</ref>
Detainees, who were subject to regular and severe beatings, were also required to engage in torturing each other, with the goal of discouraging past loyalties.<ref>Cesereanu; Cioroianu, p. 317; Rusan</ref> Guards would force them to attend scheduled or ad-hoc political instruction sessions, on topics such as [[dialectical materialism]] and [[Joseph Stalin]]'s ''History of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|CPSU(B)]] Short Course'', usually accompanied by random violence and encouraged [[Delator|delation]] (''demascare'', lit. "unmasking") for various real or invented misdemeanors.<ref name="Cesereanu; Cioroianu, p.317"/>
Each subject of the experiment was initially thoroughly [[interrogation|interrogated]], with torture applied as a mean to expose intimate details of his life ("external unmasking").<ref name="Cesereanu; Cioroianu, p.317">Cesereanu; Cioroianu, p. 317</ref> Hence, they were required to reveal everything they were thought to have hidden from previous interrogations; hoping to escape torture, many prisoners would confess imaginary misdeeds.<ref name="Cioroianu, p.317">Cioroianu, p. 317</ref> The second phase, "internal unmasking", required the tortured to reveal the names of those who had behaved less brutal or somewhat indulgently towards them in detention.<ref name="Cesereanu; Cioroianu, p.317"/>
[[Public humiliation]] was also enforced, usually at the third stage ("public moral unmasking"),<ref name="Cesereanu; Cioroianu, p.317"/> inmates were forced to denounce all their personal beliefs, loyalties, and values. Notably, religious inmates had to [[blaspheme]] religious symbols and sacred texts.<ref name="Cioroianu, p.317"/> According to [[Virgil Ierunca]]—anti-communist activist and member of the Presidential Commission for the Study of the Communist Dictatorship in Romania—Christian baptism was gruesomely mocked. Guards chanted baptismal rites as buckets of urine and fecal matter were brought to inmates. The inmate's head was pushed into the raw sewage. His head would remain submerged almost to the point of death. The head was then raised, the inmate allowed to breathe, only to have his head pushed back into the sewage.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Black Book of Communism. "The Other Europe: Central and Southeastern Europe." Harvard University Press, Cambridge, 1999. 421. Print.|last=Bartosek|first=Karel|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=1999|isbn=|location=Harvard University Press|pages=421|quote=|via=}}</ref> Ierunca further states that "prisoners' whole bodies were burned with cigarettes; their buttocks would begin to rot, and their skin fell off as though they suffered from leprosy. Others were forced to swallow spoons of excrement, and when they threw it back up, they were forced to eat their own vomit." <ref>{{Cite book|title=The Black Book of Communism|last=Bartosek|first=Karel|work=|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=1996|isbn=|location=Cambridge|pages=421|quote="Prisoners' whole bodies were burned with cigarettes: their buttocks would begin to rot, and their skin fell off as though they suffered from leprosy. Others were forced to swallow spoonfuls of excrement, and when they threw it back up, they were forced to eat their own vomit."|via=}}</ref> The inmates were required to accept the notion that their own family members had various criminal and grotesque features; they were required to author false autobiographies, comprising accounts of deviant behavior.<ref name="Cesereanu; Cioroianu, p.317" />
In addition to physical violence, inmates subject to "reeducation" were supposed to work for exhausting periods in humiliating jobs (for example, cleaning the floor with a rag clenched between the teeth). Inmates were [[Malnutrition|malnourished]] and kept in degrading and unsanitary conditions.<ref name="Cioroianu, p. 318">Cioroianu, p. 318</ref>
Historian [[Adrian Cioroianu]] argued that techniques used by the ODCC were ultimately derived from [[Anton Makarenko]]'s controversial [[pedagogy]] and [[penology]] principles in respect to [[Rehabilitation (penology)|rehabilitation]].<ref name="Cioroianu, p.317"/>
The prison also ensured a preliminary selection for the [[labor camp]]s at the [[Danube-Black Sea Canal]], [[Ocnele Mari]], and other sites, where squads of former inmates were supposed to extend the experiment.<ref name="Cioroianu, p.317"/>
===Ending and legacy=== In 1952, as [[Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej]] successfully maneuvered against the [[List of Romanian Ministers of the Interior|Minister of the Interior]] [[Teohari Georgescu]], the process was stopped by the authorities themselves.<ref name="Rusan"/> The ODCC secretly faced trial for [[abuse]], and over twenty [[death sentence]]s were handed out (Ţurcanu was held responsible for the murder of 30 prisoners, and the abuse exercised on 780 others);<ref name="Cioroianu, p. 318"/> [[Securitate]] officials who had overseen the experiment, including Colonel Teodor Sepeanu, were tried the following year; all were given light sentences, and were freed soon after.<ref>Rusan; Wexler</ref> Responding to new ideological guidelines, the court concluded that the experiment had been the result of successful infiltration of [[United States|American]] and [[Horia Sima]]'s Iron Guard agents into the Securitate, with the goal of discrediting Romanian law enforcement.<ref>Cioroianu, p. 318; Rusan</ref>
Abandoned and partially in ruin, the building was sold to a construction firm in 1991 (after the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989|Revolution of 1989]]; several of the facilities have either been torn down or suffered major changes).<ref name="Popa"/> A memorial was built in front of the prison's entrance.<ref name="Popa"/>
According to the Romanian historian Mircea Stanescu, tens of people died in the "Pitești experiment", but its aim was not to kill the people, but to "reeducate" them.<ref>Mircea Stănescu, Reeducare în România comunisă, Polirom, Iaşi, Vol. I: 2010, Vol. II:2010, vol. III: 2012)http://www.polirom.ro/catalog/carte/reeducarea-in-romania-comunista-1945-1952---3656/detalii.html. See also, Elena Dragomir, Mircea Stănescu, 'The Media vs. Historical Accuracy. How Romania's Current Communist Trials Are Being Misrepresented', http://www.balkanalysis.com/romania/2015/01/11/the-media-vs-historical-accuracy-how-romanias-current-communist-trials-are-being-misrepresented</ref>

O introducere în istoria comunismului românesc'' ("On the Shoulders of Marx. An Incursion into the History of Romanian Communism"), [[Editura Curtea Veche]], Bucharest, 2005 *[[Virgil Ierunca]], ''Piteşti'', Editura Limite, Madrid, 1981 *{{ro icon}} Ilie Popa, [http://revista.memoria.ro/?location=view_article&id=650 "''Memoria'' în prezent" ("''Memoria'' at Present")], in ''Memoria'' *{{ro icon}} [[Romulus Rusan]], [http://www.memorialsighet.ro/geografia-si-cronologia-gulagului-romanesc/ ''Geografia si cronologia Gulagului romanesc'' ("The Geography and Chronology of the Romanian Gulag")], at the Sighet Memorial site *{{ro icon}} Cassian Maria Spiridon, [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/TATAsep3.html "Tragedia Piteşti"], ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', September 2003 *{{ro icon}} Teodor Wexler, [http://revista.memoria.ro/?location=view_article&id=419 "Procesul sioniştilor" ("Trial of the Zionists")], in ''Memoria'' *{{en icon}} Elena Dragomir, Mircea Stănescu, 'The Media vs. Historical Accuracy. How Romania's Current Communist Trials Are Being Misrepresented', http://www.balkanalysis.com/romania/2015/01/11/the-media-vs-historical-accuracy-how-romanias-current-communist-trials-are-being-misrepresented *{{ro icon}} Mircea Stănescu, Reeducare în România comunisă, Polirom, Iaşi, Vol. I: 2010, Vol. II:2010, vol.
